Dear Community
I am facing an issue with Java Chaincode Deployment for a 2 days now, it´s a strange symptom
I put the chaincode locally on the node where the peer is running
and trigger the deploy transaction via the REST API
the Hyperledger Network picks up the request and creates the Docker Images and Java Containers for the chaincode
then suddenly it decides to stop & remove the containers
the Java Chaincode runs locally and it´s a sample which has worked in many infrastructures, so the issue is not with the chaincode itself
I also don´t get any compilation issues within the log of the peers
Got exception like this:

[33mvp1_1  |[0m [36m09:48:30.326 [chaincode] launchAndWaitForRegister -> DEBU 43e[0m stopping due to error while launching Timeout expired while starting chaincode e49d27c1984c636ea7ec36708b15ca69d1b32004cb87b596757cec0d064a91f14901d2fa11bd14ad95a77f29482f29078b1102557ae5d39fe2a319dbab69b8db(networkid:dev,peerid:vp1,tx:e49d27c1984c636ea7ec36708b15ca69d1b32004cb87b596757cec0d064a91f14901d2fa11bd14ad95a77f29482f29078b1102557ae5d39fe2a319dbab69b8db)

<@U3PEEM2UQ|nicoj> has joined the channel
<@U0YS0MWP3|dan-z> has joined the channel

<@U36RKMPBQ> Hello Bertalan I have yet to work with java chaincode so something may be going on that's way out of my league, but...  I will tell you that if your docker containers fail to launch they will be deleted, so when you say it 'suddenly stops and deletes your containers', the reason is that something went wrong and it gave up.  The other thing I noticed in your logs, if I read the timestamps correctly, is that it seems to be just over 5 minutes after your deploy started when you got the timeout message.   5 minutes equals 300 seconds, which is a nice round number that maybe matches some piece of software's timeout setting somewhere along the line.   

Here's a possibility, and I'm just brainstorming in the dark here-   there is something wrong with your network setup-  now if your containers are being spun up in the first place, that means your peer is talking to your Docker daemon successfully....now I'm pretty sure that when a container is spun up, it needs to POST back to the Docker daemon that it was spun up successfully.   But unless you have the world's largest chaincode or the world's slowest network, five minutes should have been plenty of time for the happy path to work, so I suspect for some reason the communication from the chaincode container back to the Docker daemon is messed up.  

First thing I'd try is, I see you're using two peers....have you tried it with just one peer yet to see if that works....I'd try to get that working first.   I wonder if there aren't some *iptables* rules or something like that getting in the way here.   I'm not a networking expert and I'm flying blind here but I'd check all your networking-related settings and see if you don't spot something.

Hope this gives you a jumpstart on your debugging.
